class Graphics

Detailed Description

Problem information.

Author:
Erion Plaku
Remarks:
Input
  • n polygonal obstacles O_1, O_2, ..., O_n
  • m reward regions R_1, R_2, ..., R_m, where each reward region is a circle and has an associated value R_i.value
  • one robot that can translate and rotate (geometry of robot corresponds to a rectangle)
  • tmax: upper bound on computation time
Objective
  • Compute as quickly as possible (within the time bound) a collision-free path that maximizes the total rewards collected by the robot. A robot collects the i-th reward iff the robot center enters the circle of the i-th reward region along the path.

Simulator provides functionality to access information about the obstacles, the reward regions, and the robot. The simulator also allows the user to

  • set the current orientation and position of the robot
  • check whether the robot in its current placement is in collision with the obstacles
  • check whether the robot center in its current placement is inside the i-th reward region

int Simulator::GetNrObstacles ( void   )  const [inline]

References m_obstacles.

int Simulator::GetObstacleNrVertices ( const int  i  )  const [inline]

Get number of vertices of the i-th obstacle.

References m_obstacles.

const double* Simulator::GetObstacleVertices ( const int  i  )  const [inline]

Get vertices of the i-th obstacle.

Remarks:
Each obstacle is represented as a polygon. You can obtain the vertices of the i-th obstacle by calling this function as follows
const double *vertices = m_simulator->GetObstacleVertices(i);
Then, the x-coordinate of the j-th vertex is given by
vertices[2 * j]
and the y-coordinate of the j-th vertex is given by
vertices[2 * j + 1]

References m_obstacles.

void Simulator::SetRobotOrientationAndPosition ( const double  theta,
const double  x,
const double  y 
)

Set robot orientation and position.

Parameters:
theta new orientation of the robot (theta is in radians)
x new x-coordinate of robot's center
y new y-coordinate of robot's center
Description
In its default frame the robot is placed so that the center is at (0, 0), i.e., geometry of the robot corresponds to the following rectangle
(-length/2, -width/2) (length/2, -width/2) (length/2, width/2) (-length/2, width/2)
This function has the effect of first rotating the robot by an angle theta and then translating the robot by (x, y)

bool Simulator::IsRobotInCollision ( void   )  const

bool Simulator::IsRobotCenterInsideRewardRegion ( const int  i  )  const

Return true iff the robot center is inside the i-th reward region.

Remarks:
The robot accumulates the i-th reward iff its center is inside the i-th reward region
Parameters:
i index of reward region
